title: Blessed are the (plant-based) cheesemakers
text:
Paul Best Contributor Updated Oct 11, 2019 — 11.31am , first published at 11.29am Share

In his tiny home test kitchen in the inner Melbourne suburb of Richmond, leading Australian chef Shaun Quade gets his vegan-friendly cheeses out of the fridge and invites me to try them.

To the naked eye, they look just like regular cheeses – but he’s made both the camembert wheel and gruyère from cauliflower and the feta (with mountain pepper) from hemp seed.

Shaun Quade and Veronica Fil at home. “People have been trying to make nut-free, soy-free cheese for years and years. No one has been able to crack it so far.” Tash Sorensen

“A week and a half ago that was a cauliflower on the bench,” says the ex-patron chef of two-hatted fine diner Lûmé, pointing to the camembert.

The cosy scene feels a world away from a multimillion-dollar plant-based food business, but that’s exactly what Quade and his partner Veronica Fil, a behavioural economist with a background in marketing and brand strategy, are planning to launch by early next year, in New York.

The couple have just landed $US200,000 ($298,000) in funding from Big Idea Ventures (BIV) – a New York-based venture capital-accelerator fund supporting plant-based food and alternative protein companies – and flew out on Friday to spend the next several months in Manhattan bringing their cheese business, Grounded Foods, to market.

There’s no soy, no nuts, no dairy, no gluten, no additives, no coconut oils, no lab-grown synthetics. — Veronica Fil

The accelerator program funding – based on Grounded's launch value of $US4 million – comes from a $US50 million “new protein” fund established by BIV, backed by the US food giant Tyson and the Singapore government’s investment arm.

It also comes hard on the heels of a $40,000 grant awarded in August by Mars Food Australia’s Seeds of Change Accelerator program, designed to help companies learn the ins and outs of running a business. “It’s pretty wild,” admits Fil of the strong interest shown in their fledgling venture and their departure to New York.

So what has everyone so excited for Quade’s cheeses? According to Fil, there’s nothing quite like them on the market. “There’s no soy, no nuts, no dairy, no gluten, no additives, no coconut oils, no lab-grown synthetics,” says Fil. “People have been trying to make nut-free, soy-free cheese for years and years. No one has been able to crack it so far.”
description: A Melbourne couple have landed $300,000 in funding from a New York venture fund to launch their plant-based cheeses in Manhattan.
